intro: Phyllanthus revaughanii, commonly known as the African pear, is a shrub native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its simple, opposite leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces non-edible, yellowish fruits that are often used in traditional medicine. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates. Its botanical features make it an important species in ecological and medicinal contexts.
